pullRequest.body:
Provide tooling for manipulating constructible sets in the prime spectrum of a ring.

From GrowthInGroups (LeanCamCombi)

Co-authored-by: Andrew Yang


---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [8fa706d70a](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20274/commits/8fa706d70a5c24700b4ecce9c2a1dbdb7e0c9914)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.RingTheory.Spectrum.Prime.ConstructibleSet` (new file)|1485|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ ConstructibleSetData`
`+ degBound`
`+ map`
`+ map_comp`
`+ map_id`
`+ toSet`
`+ toSet_map`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by alreadydone.
No, you're right. I had completely overlooked that it wasn't used anymore
I wonder why you can restrict to finite many `g`s? Are you only dealing with Noetherian rings or ...?
Oh I see, if the whole space is compact then any retrocompact set is compact.
It seems nothing in this file needs additive inverses yet; can you change to CommSemiring?

The mixture of `Finset` and `Fin`-tuple in this definition is an interesting desing choice. Can you explain it (in connection to your use case) in the docstring? Why not use `Finset (R Ã— Î£ n, Fin n â†’ R)`? How about `Finset (R Ã— Multiset R)` or `Finset (R Ã—Finset R)`? (I guess the sum in `degBound` won't behave well under `Finset.map` but `Multiset.map` should be fine?) How about replacing the outer `Finset` by `Multiset` to avoid `DecidableEq` required by `Finset.map`?

`Finset (R Ã— Î£ n, Fin n â†’ R)` is different from what we have here. It only has one $$f \in R$$ but we have a $$f_i$$ and a family of $$g_{i, j}$$ for each component $$i$$. And we use indexed family because we need a fixed number of $$g_{i, j}$$'s for each $$i$$. Changing the outermost `Finset` to `Multiset` might be fine but I'm not sure if it is an improvement.

I'm not sure I understand; they are in canonical bijection because products distribute over sums:
```
import Mathlib
example : (Î£ n, R Ã— (Fin n â†’ R)) â‰ƒ R Ã— Î£ n, Fin n â†’ R where
  toFun f := âŸ¨f.2.1, f.1, f.2.2âŸ©
  invFun f := âŸ¨f.2.1, f.1, f.2.2âŸ©
  left_inv _ := rfl
  right_inv _ := rfl
```
I seems you are giving a different reason for the choice of `Fin`-tuple over Finset than the one I guessed; it would be helpful to explain in the docstring what you mean by "a fixed number of $g_{i,j}$'s", and where and how you need them.

The reason we want to deal with indexed families rather than (fin)sets is that indexed families are easier to deal with than (fin)sets. I'm sure we could do Chevalley with (fin)sets but it doesn't really seem worth trying. I also don't really think it's worth explaining, since it's very possible we're wrong

pullRequest.title: feat: constructible sets in the prime spectrum
